sn55.40:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
sn55.40:1.2: Then Nandiya the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn55.40:1.3: “Sir, if a noble disciple were to totally and utterly lack the four factors of stream-entry, would they live negligently?”
sn55.40:2.1: “Nandiya, someone who totally and utterly lacks these four factors of stream-entry is an outsider who belongs with the ordinary persons, I say.
sn55.40:2.2: Neverthless, Nandiya, as to how a noble disciple lives negligently and how they live diligently,
sn55.40:2.3: listen and attend closely, I will speak.
sn55.40:3.1: “And how does a noble disciple live negligently?
sn55.40:3.2: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.40:3.4: They’re content with that confidence, and don’t make a further effort for solitude by day or retreat by night.
sn55.40:3.5: When they live negligently, there’s no joy.
sn55.40:3.6: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.
sn55.40:3.7: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
sn55.40:3.8: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.
sn55.40:3.9: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.
sn55.40:3.10: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
sn55.40:3.11: Because principles have not become clear, they’re reckoned to live negligently.
sn55.40:4.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …
sn55.40:4.3: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.
sn55.40:4.4: They’re content with that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, and don’t make a further effort for solitude by day or retreat by night.
sn55.40:4.5: When they live negligently, there’s no joy.
sn55.40:4.6: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.
sn55.40:4.7: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
sn55.40:4.8: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.
sn55.40:4.9: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.
sn55.40:4.10: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
sn55.40:4.11: Because principles have not become clear, they’re reckoned to live negligently.
sn55.40:4.12: That’s how a noble disciple lives negligently.
sn55.40:5.1: And how does a noble disciple live diligently?
sn55.40:5.2: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.40:5.4: But they’re not content with that confidence, and make a further effort for solitude by day and retreat by night.
sn55.40:5.5: When they live diligently, joy springs up.
sn55.40:5.7: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
sn55.40:5.8: When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.
sn55.40:5.9: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
sn55.40:5.10: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.
sn55.40:5.11: Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.
sn55.40:6.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …
sn55.40:6.3: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.
sn55.40:6.4: But they’re not content with that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, and make a further effort for solitude by day and retreat by night.
sn55.40:6.5: When they live diligently, joy springs up.
sn55.40:6.7: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
sn55.40:6.8: When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.
sn55.40:6.9: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
sn55.40:6.10: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.
sn55.40:6.11: Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.
sn55.40:6.12: That’s how a noble disciple lives diligently.”
